customer_name: Exotic Animal Encounter DBA Debbie Dolittle's Petting Zoo

site_name: Exotic Animal Encounter DBA Debbie Dolittle's Petting Zoo

citations.narrative:
Several enclosures in the main room have wood boards that have been chewed by the animals. These enclosures are:
- The second enclosure from the right side of the main door on the eastern side of the building.
- The circular pen in the middle of the first room.
- The small pen on the left side of the main door of the first room.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Correct by: August 17, 2025.

The capybaras are rotated between indoors and an outdoors enclosure. Both enclosures have water receptacles for
immersion, bathing, and swimming. However, the indoor receptacle lacks surface and depth for the species to make
normal postural and social adjustments with freedom of movement.
The indoor water receptacle is a Rubbermaid 150-gal Stock Tank for livestock, and it is not large enough for the animals
to at least submerge their bodies into water. The outdoor water receptacle is a large round galvanized water trough. The
ramp to access the receptacle is too steep, making ingress and egress difficult for the animals. Capybaras spend a
significant portion of their time in water under natural conditions. Appropriate water access and aquatic areas for the
species can help maintain healthy skin. Two female capybaras had areas of hair loss.
To comply with space requirements there should be both dry and aquatic portions in the primary enclosure, each which,
at a minimum, provides sufficient space to allow the animal to make normal postural adjustments with adequate freedom
of movement.
Correct by: October 17, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several enclosures in the main room have wood boards that have been chewed by the animals. These enclosures are:  
 
- The second enclosure from the right side of the main door on the eastern side of the building.  
- The circular pen in the middle of the first room. 
- The small pen on the left side of the main door of the first room. 
 
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
Correct by: August 17, 2025. 
3.128 
   
Space requirements. 
The capybaras are rotated between indoors and an outdoors enclosure. Both enclosures have water receptacles for 
immersion, bathing, and swimming. However, the indoor receptacle lacks surface and depth for the species to make 
normal postural and social adjustments with freedom of movement.  
 
The indoor water receptacle is a Rubbermaid 150-gal Stock Tank for livestock, and it is not large enough for the animals 
to at least submerge their bodies into water. The outdoor water receptacle is a large round galvanized water trough. The 
ramp to access the receptacle is too steep, making ingress and egress difficult for the animals. Capybaras spend a 
significant portion of their time in water under natural conditions. Appropriate water access and aquatic areas for the 
species can help maintain healthy skin. Two female capybaras had areas of hair loss. 
 
To comply with space requirements there should be both dry and aquatic portions in the primary enclosure, each which, 
at a minimum, provides sufficient space to allow the animal to make normal postural adjustments with adequate freedom 
of movement.

Correct by: October 17, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
